answers.text: a single-stranded RNA molecule known as messenger RNA

qas.question: How does the nucleotide sequence of mRNA compare to DNA?

answers.text: complementary to the DNA from which it was transcribed

qas.question: What is used as a template to generate a complementary mRNA?
Why does the mRNA match the sequence of the gene's DNA coding strand?

answers.text: because it is synthesised as the complement of the template strand

qas.question: What is the enzyme called that performs transcription?

context: Transcription produces <a0_0>a single-stranded RNA molecule known as messenger RNA<a0_0/>, whose nucleotide sequence is <a1_0>complementary to the DNA from which it was transcribed<a1_0/>.:6.1 The mRNA acts as an intermediate between the DNA gene and its final protein product. <a2_0>The gene's DNA<a2_0/> is used as a template to generate a complementary mRNA. The mRNA matches the sequence of the gene's DNA coding strand <a3_0>because it is synthesised as the complement of the template strand<a3_0/>. Transcription is performed by an enzyme called <a4_0>an RNA polymerase<a4_0/>, which reads the template strand in the 3' to 5' direction and synthesizes the RNA from 5' to 3'. To initiate transcription, the polymerase first recognizes and binds a promoter region of the gene. Thus, a major mechanism of gene regulation is the blocking or sequestering the promoter region, either by tight binding by repressor molecules that physically block the polymerase, or by organizing the DNA so that the promoter region is not accessible.:7
